author: marioevz
content:
Hey <@403707149043105803>, I'm making some changes to the branch in #540, all in all, I think `tests/prague/eip7692_eof_v1/eip6206_jumpf/helpers.py` should no longer be necessary.

I'll make a PR to your branch and we can discuss if the changes are ok

author: marioevz
content: <@403707149043105803> I created a PR https://github.com/shemnon/execution-spec-tests/pull/1/files to your branch, basically `execute_tests` helper is now replaced by a new `EOFStateTest`, which creates an EOF fixture and a state test

author: _shemnon
content: Will merge.  Looks like it collided with some of my slot naming work.

author: marioevz
content: Thanks! üôè I'll continue with the PRs tomorrow, I think we can reuse this `EOFStateTest` in more places

author: _shemnon
content: Yes, so as a broad policu if you are testing code validaion as the intent use the EOF state test (with a very simple end test), if it's execution just StateTest?

author: marioevz
content:
Yes I think something like this:
- EOFTest: pure code validation, no running necessary
- EOFStateTest: code validation + execution validation
- StateTest: anything involving ~~more than 1 tx~~ multiple contracts or something more complex

author: jochembrouwer
content: Just want to chime in here, code is validated at deposit time right, so is EOFStateTest necessary? Also I don't think I recall having state tests with more than 1 tx in it ever (from viewpoint of `ethereum/tests`)

author: jochembrouwer
content: (deposit time = EOF contract creation)

author: _shemnon
content: A creation transation the only time in the current spec it has to be validated since all containers are deeply validated.  RETURNCONTRACT implies some light validation, and that just size checking and a container re-write (that can mostly be done in-place).

author: _shemnon
content: I do run validation when loading test ALLOCs, and hence when an EOF contract appears at genesis.

author: marioevz
content: We could add a creation transaction to EOFStateTest

author: marioevz
content: Since I assume the `Alloc` validation and deploy validation could differ?

author: marioevz
content: the logic I mean

author: _shemnon
content: Then we would need to wrap it into a contract deployment.

author: _shemnon
content: Contracts in an Alloc will be "runtime" contracts that can RETURN/STOP.  Create transactions must RETURNCONTRACT.  or REVERT for both.

author: marioevz
content: We might need to write this wrapper
